multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main difference in the Galactic distribution between HMXBs (top) and LMXBs (bottom)?
choices: HMXBs are more concentrated towards the Galactic center.
LMXBs are mostly found in globular clusters and the Galactic bulge.
HMXBs display a more scattered distribution throughout the Galaxy.
LMXBs are exclusively found in the Galactic plane.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does the horizontal dotted line in the top panel of Figure 2 represent?
choices: The separation between neutron star and black hole masses.
The division between LMXBs/IMXBs and HMXBs.
The average mass of a neutron star in an X-ray binary.
The mass limit for a compact object to become a black hole.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the significance of the "mass gap" observed in the distribution of compact object masses (top panel), and how do theoretical models explain its existence (bottom panel)?
choices: The gap represents a lack of observed objects with masses between ~2-5 solar masses, potentially explained by rapid growth of turbulent instabilities during supernovae.
The gap indicates a measurement bias towards heavier objects, and theoretical models suggest a continuous mass distribution.
The gap signifies a period of inactivity in star formation, and models predict it will be filled with future observations.
The gap demonstrates the limitations of current observational techniques, with theoretical models unable to explain its presence.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Formula (4) describe, and what key assumption does it rely on for determining neutron star masses in LMXBs?
choices: The relationship between the rotational velocity of the donor star and the binary mass ratio, assuming the donor star underfills its Roche lobe.
The gravitational force between the neutron star and the donor star, assuming the binary system is in thermal equilibrium.
The radius of the accretion disk around the neutron star, assuming the system is observed edge-on.
The rate of mass transfer from the donor star to the neutron star, assuming the donor star is a red giant.
